text:
Soundview Avenue, west side, south Lafayette Avenue. Shown are the grounds and buildings of the Clason Point Military Academy. On the left, among the trees, is the Dominick Lynch House, where the committee to design the American flag met before proceeding to Philadelphia. The building in the center is the chapel.

E. P. Chrystie

June 17, 1923

Soundview Avenue, west side, south of Lafayette Avenue, showing the Clason Point Military Academy. The view is northward with the school and chapel appearing on the right. In the center is the old Dominick Lynch Mansion, a stone structure. In this house was celebrated the first mass in Westchester County and the committee to design the American flag met here before proceeding to Philadelphia. The land in this area was owned by Lynch in 1793, part of which was sold, in the same year, to Issac Classon, whence the name is derived. In 1870 the mansion was bought by the Christian Brothers of the Catholic Faith, who changed it into the Sacred Heart Academy in 1883. It later became part of the Clason Point Military Academy.

June, 1926

Brown Brothers

Soundview Avenue, west side, south of Lafayette Avenue, showing the Clason Point Military Academy, viewing southwestward toward the East River. On the left is the school building. The Academy was later abandoned and the area developed into a residential section.

June, 1926

Brown Brothers

Soundview Avenue, south from Lafayette Avenue. On the west side of the Avenue (right) is the Clason Point Military Academy.

June 1926

Brown Brothers

(1)
Soundview Avenue, east side, at Lafayette Avenue, showing the old J. Husson house and farm. Beers' and Bien's Westchester County maps of 1867 and 1893, respectively, show it to have belonged to the Husson family.

July 30, 1928.

P.L. Sperr

(2)
A more distant view of the house from near Rosedale Avenue.

July 30, 1928.

P.L. Sperr
